context: NATO defines anti-aircraft warfare (AAW) as "measures taken to defend a maritime force against attacks by airborne weapons launched from aircraft, ships, submarines and land-based sites." In some armies the term <a0_0>All-Arms Air Defence<a0_0/> (AAAD) is used for air defence by non-specialist troops. Other terms from the late 20th century include GBAD (<a1_0>Ground Based AD<a1_0/>) with related terms SHORAD (<a2_0>Short Range AD<a2_0/>) and MANPADS ("<a3_0>Man Portable AD Systems<a3_0/>": typically shoulder-launched missiles). Anti-aircraft missiles are variously called surface-to-air missile, abbreviated and pronounced "SAM" and <a4_0>Surface to Air Guided Weapon<a4_0/> (SAGW).
